Commutative Law
A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
Ring

A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
Zero Divisor

An element a of a ring R is called a zero divisor if there exists an element b in R - {0} such that ab=0 or ba=0. Fields and skew fields do not admit any zero divisors, except for 0, the trivial zero divisor.
Trivial Ideals
In any ring $R$, the zero ideal $\{0\}$ and the unit ideal $R$ are called trivial ideals. These are the only ideals if $R$ is a field.
Greatest common divisor

An element $d \in R$ is called a greatest common divisor of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $d \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $d$ is a common divisor of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common divisor of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $a \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $a \mid d$.
Prime Element

An element $p$ in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called a prime element if it generates a prime ideal, i.e., the ideal $(p)$ is such that if $p$ divides a product of elements in $R$, then $p$ divides at least one of those elements.
Separable Polynomial
A separable polynomial is a polynomial that has distinct roots in its splitting field, i.e., all roots are simple.
Algebra over a Ring

An algebra $B$ over a ring $A$ is defined as a ring homomorphism $A \longrightarrow B$. A homomorphism between two $A$-algebras $B$ and $C$ is a ring homomorphism $B \longrightarrow C$ that is compatible with the defining homomorphisms $A \longrightarrow B$ and $A \longrightarrow C$, ensuring the commutativity of the diagram involving these maps.
Trivial Algebraic field extension
An algebraic field extension $L / K$ is trivial if every element of $L$ is algebraic over $K$.
Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
Symmetric Group
The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.
Inheritance_Analysis

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: Trivial Ideals are a concept specifically defined within the context of rings, inheriting all properties and definitions that apply to rings.
Zero Divisor is a concept defined specifically for elements within a ring, thus inheriting all properties and definitions that apply to rings.
Greatest common divisor is a concept defined for elements within a ring, thus inheriting all properties and definitions that apply to rings.
Prime Element is defined within the context of a unique factorization domain, which is a type of ring, thus inheriting all properties and definitions that apply to rings.
An algebra over a ring is defined through a ring homomorphism from a ring A to another ring B, thus inheriting all properties and definitions that apply to rings.
